title: Figma targets marketers with three new Figma Buzz features for faster, on‑brand campaigns

paragraphs.content: Figma is rolling out three new capabilities in Figma Buzz—configurable templates built on design systems, plugin access, and native video trimming—aimed at helping teams ship more on-brand marketing assets with less friction.The update lets brand designers publish flexible templates powered by component properties so marketers can swap layouts, imagery, and copy without straying from guidelines.Plugins bring digital asset management, translation, and animation tools directly into the Buzz canvas, reducing context switching across multiple SaaS platforms.Built-in video trimming finally lets users fine-tune clips inside Buzz itself, eliminating the need to jump into separate video editors for timing and sync tweaks.

paragraphs.content: Community curators note that templates built with Variable modes now work seamlessly when published to Buzz, giving marketing teams a simple way to toggle between brand modes such as colors, campaigns, and markets.Figmalion’s roundup also highlights one-click “Add all” template actions and new admin controls that let Organization and Enterprise customers turn off Community templates to enforce brand-approved options only.In parallel, Figma’s release-notes stream positions Buzz alongside other surfaces like Make, Sites, and Draw, underscoring the company’s push to connect design systems directly to customer-facing experiences.Investor materials further elevate the Buzz update as a flagship announcement, signaling that brand and marketing workflows are becoming a core pillar of Figma’s growth story.

sections.title: Design-system templates and plugins bring governance and flexibility to Figma Buzz

paragraphs.content: Figma’s announcement stresses that Buzz templates are now “connected to your design system,” allowing designers to copy component-based templates from Figma Design and paste them into Buzz with properties intact.Short-form video explainers show how marketers can use dropdowns and toggles in the “Change layout” panel to switch layouts or turn elements on and off without modifying underlying components.These demos frame Buzz as a bridge between product design systems and day-to-day campaign work, with component properties and variables handling complexity behind the scenes.In parallel, Figma’s YouTube Shorts content packages the three pillars—templates from component properties, precise video trimming, and plugins—as a concise checklist of what’s new in Buzz for 2026.

paragraphs.content: Beyond templates, Figma is bringing its mature plugin ecosystem into Buzz, starting with integrations for digital asset management, translation platforms, and motion design. Official materials describe how teams can pull in brand-approved images from DAM tools, localize copy from translation systems, and add animations or QR codes without leaving the Buzz canvas. Figma emphasizes that organizations can also build internal-only plugins or share them with the wider Community, effectively encoding custom brand rules and workflows directly into the interface. On related solution pages, the company portrays this integration-first approach as part of a broader strategy to keep every touchpoint—from interactive demos to small-business websites—visually and behaviorally consistent with a single design system.

sections.title: Video trimming and AI-powered workflows push Buzz deeper into marketing territory

paragraphs.content: Native video trimming in Buzz gives teams finer control over how clips appear in social posts, ads, and other multimedia assets without leaving Figma. Figma recounts how Product Designer Natasha Tenggoro used Figma Make to prototype complex playback behaviors, from video collages for event pages to animated backgrounds for Instagram ads, before finalizing the trimming feature. Around the same period, Figma expanded its ChatGPT integration so users can generate Buzz assets via the Figma app inside ChatGPT, then open and refine them in Figma. Agency and community explainers describe Buzz as “revolutionizing design collaboration” by giving marketers and non-designers a space to work alongside designers on shared, on-brand materials.

paragraphs.content: Figma’s own blog frames these Buzz upgrades as part of a continuum of “new features” that deepen customization and control across its platform, from grid and drawing tools to AI-assisted site and demo creation. Coverage in design news aggregators echoes that positioning, presenting the three Buzz features as a response to teams that want Canva-like speed but with enterprise-grade design systems and governance. Looking ahead, investor and community channels suggest that tighter links between AI generation, design systems, and marketing surfaces like Buzz will shape Figma’s roadmap, even as regional rollouts and enterprise controls continue to evolve. For now, the trio of configurable templates, plugins, and video trimming marks Figma’s clearest bid yet to make Buzz a central hub for brand expression, not just another design surface.
